description: From Anglo-Norman temperance, from Latin temperantia (“moderation, sobriety, discretion, self-control”), from temperans, present participle of temperare (“to moderate”). See temper. English equivalent temper +‎ -ance.

entries.meaning: Habitual moderation in regard to the indulgence of the natural appetites and passions; restrained or moderate indulgence
examples: temperance in the indulgence of joy

entries.meaning: Moderation, and sometimes abstinence, in respect to using intoxicating liquors.
(obsolete) State with regard to heat or cold; temperature.
